questions.question: For 2024, what is the maximum deduction for cash contributions to public charities as a percentage of adjusted gross income?
questions.explanation: Cash contributions to public charities (50% limit organizations) are deductible up to 60% of AGI. This limit was made permanent after initially being introduced as a temporary provision.
questions.tip: Cash to public charity = 60% AGI limit; appreciated capital gain property = 30% AGI limit.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a qualified charitable organization for income tax deduction purposes?

options.B: A state government
options.C: A political campaign committee
options.D: A religious organization

questions.explanation: Political campaign committees and political parties are not qualified charitable organizations. Contributions to them are not deductible, though they may have separate political contribution rules.
questions.tip: Political contributions ≠ charitable contributions. Not deductible for income tax.

questions.question: A taxpayer donates publicly traded stock held for 3 years with a basis of $5,000 and fair market value of $15,000 to a public charity. What is the deductible amount (assuming no AGI limitations apply)?
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain property donated to a public charity is generally deductible at fair market value. The taxpayer deducts $15,000 and avoids recognizing the $10,000 gain—a double tax benefit.
questions.tip: Appreciated LTCG property to public charity = FMV deduction + bypass capital gains.

questions.question: For a cash contribution of $300, what documentation is required to claim a charitable deduction?

options.B: A canceled check or receipt from the charity
options.C: A written acknowledgment from the charity
options.D: A qualified appraisal

questions.explanation: Cash contributions of any amount require documentation (bank record, receipt, etc.). Written acknowledgments from the charity are required for single contributions of $250 or more. A $300 contribution requires a written acknowledgment.
questions.tip: $250+ single contribution = written acknowledgment from charity required.

questions.question: A taxpayer's charitable contributions exceed the AGI limitation. How long can the excess be carried forward?

options.B: 5 years
options.C: 7 years
options.D: Indefinitely

questions.explanation: Charitable contributions exceeding the AGI limitation can be carried forward for 5 years. The carryforward maintains its character and is subject to the same limitations in future years.
questions.tip: Charitable contribution carryforward = 5 years. Same character maintained.

questions.question: A taxpayer pays $500 to a charity for a dinner where the meal value is $75. What is the deductible charitable contribution?
questions.explanation: When a taxpayer receives something of value in return for a payment to charity (quid pro quo), only the excess over the value received is deductible. $500 - $75 = $425 deductible.
questions.tip: Quid pro quo: Deduction = payment minus value received.

questions.question: A donor creates a charitable remainder annuity trust (CRAT) with a 7% payout rate. If the trust is funded with $1 million, what annual payment does the income beneficiary receive?

options.B: 7% of the trust value each year, which varies
options.C: $70,000 the first year, increasing with inflation
options.D: The lesser of 7% or actual trust income

questions.explanation: A CRAT pays a fixed annuity amount determined at creation. With a 7% rate on $1 million, the annual payment is $70,000 regardless of trust performance. A CRUT (unitrust) would pay a varying percentage of annually revalued assets.
questions.tip: CRAT = fixed annuity; CRUT = percentage of annually revalued assets.

questions.question: A taxpayer contributes $100,000 to a donor advised fund (DAF) in December 2024. The taxpayer recommends grants to specific charities in 2025. When is the charitable deduction available?

options.B: 2025, when grants are recommended
options.C: When the charities actually receive the grants
options.D: Split between 2024 and 2025

questions.explanation: The charitable deduction is available when the contribution is made to the DAF sponsoring organization, not when grants are subsequently made to charities. The DAF contribution is complete and irrevocable in 2024.
questions.tip: DAF deduction = year of contribution to DAF, not year of grant distribution.

questions.question: A 72-year-old taxpayer wants to make a qualified charitable distribution (QCD) from their IRA. Which statement is correct?

options.A: The QCD can be made to a donor advised fund
options.B: The maximum annual QCD is $105,000 per taxpayer (2024)
options.C: The QCD is included in income but offset by a charitable deduction
options.D: The taxpayer must be at least age 72 to make a QCD

questions.explanation: QCDs are limited to $105,000 per taxpayer per year for 2024 (indexed for inflation under SECURE 2.0). QCDs cannot be made to DAFs or private foundations. The taxpayer must be 70½ or older. QCDs are excluded from income entirely (not included then deducted).
questions.tip: QCD: 70½+ age, $105K limit (2024, indexed), excludes from income, not to DAFs/PFs.

questions.question: Cash contributions to a private foundation are generally limited to what percentage of AGI?
questions.explanation: Cash contributions to private foundations are limited to 30% of AGI (compared to 60% for public charities). Appreciated property contributions to private foundations are limited to 20% of AGI and generally valued at basis rather than FMV.
questions.tip: Private foundation limits: 30% cash, 20% property (usually at basis).

questions.question: A charitable lead annuity trust (CLAT) provides income to charity for 15 years, then remainder to the grantor's children. What is the primary transfer tax benefit?

options.A: Income tax deduction for annual payments to charity
options.B: Reduced gift tax value because charity receives income first
options.C: Estate tax deduction for the full value transferred
options.D: Elimination of capital gains on appreciated assets

questions.explanation: A non-grantor CLAT reduces the taxable gift to the present value of the remainder interest after the charity's income interest. This can be significantly less than the full value transferred, especially with longer terms or higher payout rates.
questions.tip: CLT = charity gets income first, reducing gift/estate tax on remainder to family.

questions.question: An art collector donates a painting worth $100,000 (basis $20,000) to an art museum that will display it. The collector held the painting for 5 years. What is the deductible amount?
questions.explanation: When tangible personal property is donated to a charity that will use it for its exempt purpose (related use), the deduction is fair market value. The museum displaying art is a related use. If the museum sold the painting, only basis would be deductible.
questions.tip: Tangible property: Related use = FMV deduction; unrelated use = basis only.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells property with a basis of $40,000 and FMV of $100,000 to a charity for $60,000. What is the charitable deduction?
questions.explanation: The charitable deduction in a bargain sale equals FMV minus the sale price: $100,000 - $60,000 = $40,000. The taxpayer must also recognize gain on the sale portion, allocating basis proportionally.
questions.tip: Bargain sale deduction = FMV minus amount received. Basis must be allocated.

questions.question: Using the same facts (basis $40,000, FMV $100,000, sale price $60,000), what gain must the taxpayer recognize on the bargain sale?
questions.explanation: Basis is allocated: Sale portion = 60% ($60K/$100K), so allocated basis = $40,000 × 60% = $24,000. Gain = $60,000 - $24,000 = $36,000. The gift portion uses the remaining $16,000 of basis.
questions.tip: Bargain sale gain: Allocate basis proportionally between sale and gift portions.

questions.question: A landowner donates a conservation easement that reduces property value from $2 million to $500,000. The easement restricts development and is granted to a land trust in perpetuity. What is the deductible amount?

options.D: Fair market value of the easement as appraised

questions.explanation: A qualified conservation contribution is deductible at the reduction in property value caused by the easement. Here, $2,000,000 - $500,000 = $1,500,000. The easement must be perpetual and for qualified conservation purposes.
questions.tip: Conservation easement deduction = before value minus after value.

questions.question: A charitable remainder trust must satisfy the 10% remainder test. What does this requirement specify?

options.A: The charity must receive at least 10% of trust income annually
options.B: The present value of the charitable remainder must be at least 10% of initial contribution
options.C: The payout rate cannot exceed 10%
options.D: At least 10% of trust assets must be invested in charitable bonds

questions.explanation: A CRT must be structured so the present value of the charitable remainder interest is at least 10% of the net fair market value of assets contributed. This prevents CRTs from being structured to minimize the charitable benefit.
questions.tip: CRT 10% test: Present value of charity's remainder must be ≥10% of contribution.

questions.question: Distributions from a charitable remainder trust to the income beneficiary are taxed using a four-tier system. Which type of income is distributed first?

options.B: Ordinary income
options.C: Capital gains
options.D: Return of principal

questions.explanation: CRT distributions follow four tiers: (1) ordinary income, (2) capital gains, (3) other income (tax-exempt), (4) corpus/principal. Each tier is exhausted before moving to the next, with income taxed at highest rates first.
questions.tip: CRT four-tier: Ordinary → Capital gain → Tax-exempt → Corpus. Worst-in, first-out.

questions.question: A taxpayer donates inventory with a basis of $10,000 and FMV of $25,000 to a public charity. What is the charitable deduction?
questions.explanation: Inventory is ordinary income property. The deduction for ordinary income property is limited to the lower of FMV or basis. Since selling the inventory would produce ordinary income (not capital gain), the deduction is limited to $10,000 basis.
questions.tip: Ordinary income property (inventory, short-term assets) = deduction limited to basis.

questions.question: A pooled income fund differs from a charitable remainder trust in that:

options.A: PIFs can have only one donor
options.B: PIFs pay income based on fund performance, not a fixed amount or percentage
options.C: PIFs provide larger charitable deductions
options.D: PIFs can invest in tax-exempt bonds

questions.explanation: Pooled income funds combine contributions from multiple donors and pay each donor's income beneficiary a pro-rata share of actual fund income. PIFs cannot invest in tax-exempt securities. CRTs pay fixed amounts (CRAT) or fixed percentages (CRUT).
questions.tip: PIF = actual income (variable); CRT = fixed annuity or unitrust percentage.

questions.question: A taxpayer donates artwork claimed to be worth $75,000 to a museum. Which substantiation requirement applies?

options.B: Qualified appraisal and appraisal summary (Form 8283)
options.C: Canceled check or receipt
options.D: No special requirements for art donations

questions.explanation: Non-cash contributions over $5,000 require a qualified appraisal by a qualified appraiser, and the taxpayer must attach Form 8283 (Noncash Charitable Contributions) Section B to the tax return.
questions.tip: Non-cash >$5,000 = qualified appraisal + Form 8283 Section B required.

questions.question: A taxpayer with $200,000 AGI wants to donate long-term appreciated stock worth $80,000 (basis $30,000) to a public charity. Without an election, the deduction is limited to $60,000 (30% AGI). What option is available?

options.B: Elect to use basis ($30,000) and claim full deduction with 50% limit
options.C: Elect to use basis ($30,000) and claim full deduction with 60% limit
options.D: Carry forward the full $80,000 to future years

questions.explanation: A taxpayer can elect to reduce the deduction to basis, which increases the AGI limit from 30% to 50% for capital gain property. Here, electing basis deduction ($30,000) allows full current deduction under the 50% limit ($100,000).
questions.tip: Capital gain property election: Choose basis deduction for 50% limit vs FMV at 30% limit.

questions.question: A married taxpayer normally donates $15,000 annually to charity. With a $29,200 standard deduction (2024) and $20,000 of other itemized deductions, which strategy maximizes tax benefit?

options.A: Donate $15,000 each year and take standard deduction
options.B: Donate $15,000 each year and itemize
options.C: Bunch two years of donations into one year, alternating between itemizing and standard deduction
options.D: Spread donations evenly is always optimal

questions.explanation: Bunching $30,000 of donations in one year creates $50,000 itemized deductions (exceeding standard deduction by $20,800), while taking the $29,200 standard deduction the other year. Total benefit exceeds annual itemizing or standard deduction approach.
questions.tip: Bunching: Concentrate deductions to exceed standard deduction in alternate years.

questions.question: An S corporation donates appreciated property to charity. How is this treated for tax purposes?

options.B: The deduction passes through to shareholders who apply individual limitations
options.C: No deduction is allowed for S corporation charitable gifts
options.D: Shareholders receive a deduction equal to their basis in S corp stock

questions.explanation: S corporation charitable contributions pass through to shareholders as separately stated items. Each shareholder claims their pro-rata share and applies individual AGI limitations and other rules on their personal returns.
questions.tip: S corp charity: Passes through to shareholders; they apply individual limits.

questions.question: A private foundation must distribute what minimum amount annually to avoid an excise tax?

options.B: 5% of net investment assets
options.C: The greater of income or 5% of assets
options.D: 10% of contributions received

questions.explanation: Private foundations must make qualifying distributions of approximately 5% of net investment assets annually to avoid a 30% excise tax on undistributed income. This is separate from the 1.39% excise tax on net investment income.
questions.tip: Private foundation minimum distribution = 5% of investment assets annually.

questions.question: A net income with makeup charitable remainder unitrust (NIMCRUT) distributes:

options.A: A fixed percentage of trust assets annually
options.B: The lesser of trust income or the unitrust percentage, with makeup in later high-income years
options.C: Only net income regardless of unitrust percentage
options.D: The greater of trust income or unitrust percentage

questions.explanation: A NIMCRUT pays the lesser of actual trust income or the unitrust percentage in low-income years, but allows makeup of shortfalls in later years when trust income exceeds the unitrust percentage. This provides flexibility for assets that don't produce current income.
questions.tip: NIMCRUT: Lesser of income/unitrust amount, with makeup provision for shortfalls.

questions.question: A supporting organization that supports a public charity receives public charity status itself. What is the primary advantage over creating a private foundation?

options.B: Higher contribution limits and no excise taxes
options.C: Ability to engage in political activities
options.D: No requirement to file annual returns

questions.explanation: Supporting organizations are classified as public charities, giving donors higher AGI limits (60%/30% vs 30%/20%) and avoiding private foundation excise taxes on investment income and undistributed income.
questions.tip: Supporting org = public charity treatment: higher limits, no foundation excise taxes.

questions.question: A grantor creates a grantor charitable lead annuity trust (CLAT) and contributes $2 million. The present value of the annuity stream to charity is $1.4 million. What are the income tax consequences?

options.A: No current deduction; annual deductions as payments are made
options.B: $1.4 million current deduction; grantor taxed on trust income during the term
options.C: $2 million current deduction; no further tax consequences
options.D: $600,000 current deduction for the remainder interest

questions.explanation: A grantor CLAT provides an immediate income tax deduction equal to the present value of the charity's income interest ($1.4M). However, the grantor is taxed on all trust income during the trust term as owner of a grantor trust.
questions.tip: Grantor CLAT: Upfront deduction for charity's interest, but grantor taxed on trust income.

questions.question: A taxpayer contributes stock (basis $100,000, FMV $500,000) to a CRUT. The trust sells the stock and reinvests in bonds yielding 5%. What is the tax treatment of the first $25,000 distribution?

options.B: Long-term capital gain
options.C: Ordinary income
options.D: Partially capital gain, partially ordinary income

questions.explanation: Under the four-tier system, the $400,000 capital gain from the stock sale is in tier 2. The $25,000 bond income (tier 1 ordinary income) is less than the distribution, but capital gains accumulated first. The distribution comes from the undistributed capital gain tier.
questions.tip: CRT tiers carry accumulated amounts. Large embedded gains are distributed over time.

questions.question: The IRS has identified syndicated conservation easement transactions as abusive. Which characteristic is most indicative of an abusive syndicated easement?

options.A: The easement is granted to a qualified land trust
options.B: The claimed deduction significantly exceeds the investment in the partnership interest
options.C: The property has legitimate conservation value
options.D: The easement restricts residential development

questions.explanation: Abusive syndicated easements typically involve investors purchasing partnership interests shortly before an easement donation, with claimed charitable deductions far exceeding the purchase price (often 4-5x or more). The IRS and Congress have imposed strict penalties on such transactions.
questions.tip: Syndicated easement red flag: Deduction greatly exceeds investment amount.

questions.question: A taxpayer wants to donate $50,000 to charity and owns: (1) stock held 2 years with $50,000 FMV and $10,000 basis, and (2) stock held 2 years with $50,000 FMV and $45,000 basis. Which should be donated for optimal tax benefit?

options.A: Either stock—the result is the same
options.B: Stock 1 (low basis)—maximizes tax benefit
options.C: Stock 2 (high basis)—avoids capital gains
options.D: Sell both stocks and donate cash

questions.explanation: Donating highly appreciated stock (Stock 1) provides a $50,000 deduction while avoiding $40,000 of capital gain. Stock 2 should be sold (only $5,000 gain recognized) to generate cash or be held. Donating low-basis stock maximizes the tax benefit.
questions.tip: Donate low-basis appreciated stock; sell high-basis stock. Maximize bypassed gain.

questions.question: A wealthy donor wants to establish a charitable vehicle with family involvement, immediate 60% AGI deduction for cash contributions, and no minimum distribution requirements. Which vehicle best meets these criteria?

options.B: Donor advised fund
options.C: Supporting organization
options.D: Charitable remainder trust

questions.explanation: Donor advised funds provide public charity deduction limits (60% for cash), allow family advisory privileges, and have no mandatory distribution requirements. Private foundations have 30% limits and 5% distribution rules. Supporting organizations have operational requirements.
questions.tip: DAF: Public charity limits, family involvement, no mandatory distributions.

questions.question: A taxpayer in the 37% tax bracket has highly appreciated stock worth $1 million (basis $200,000). Compared to a testamentary bequest, what is the approximate additional tax benefit of a lifetime gift (assuming full use of the deduction)?

options.B: $160,000 (capital gains avoided)
options.C: $370,000 (income tax deduction)
options.D: $530,000 (income tax deduction plus capital gains avoided)

questions.explanation: Lifetime gifts provide an income tax deduction ($1M × 37% = $370,000) plus avoid capital gains ($800,000 × 20% = $160,000). A testamentary bequest provides only estate tax savings (same as the income tax deduction economically) without the capital gains benefit.
questions.tip: Lifetime charitable gift = income tax deduction + capital gains bypass. Bequest only provides one benefit.

questions.question: A taxpayer with $100,000 AGI makes contributions of: $40,000 cash to public charity, $25,000 appreciated stock to public charity, and $20,000 cash to a private foundation. What is the current year deduction?
questions.explanation: 60% limit for cash to public charity: $60,000 allows full $40,000. 30% limit for appreciated property to public charity: $30,000 allows full $25,000. 30% limit for cash to private foundation, but overall limit is 60% less amounts already used: $60,000 - $40,000 - $25,000 = -$5,000 + special $10K allowance. Total: $75,000 with complex ordering rules.
questions.tip: AGI limits stack and interact. Order: 60% cash, then 30% property, then foundations.

questions.question: A 65-year-old donor wants to fund a CRT with $2 million of stock expected to appreciate significantly. The donor wants retirement income that grows with inflation. Which trust type is most appropriate?

options.B: CRUT—payments increase as trust value grows
options.C: NIMCRUT—defers income until retirement
options.D: Pooled income fund—professional management

questions.explanation: A CRUT pays a fixed percentage of annually revalued assets, so if assets appreciate, payments increase. This provides inflation protection. A CRAT pays a fixed dollar amount regardless of growth. For expected appreciation and inflation protection, CRUT is preferred.
questions.tip: CRUT for growth/inflation protection; CRAT for fixed, predictable payments.

questions.question: A business owner wants to sell their $10 million company, provide lifetime income, benefit charity, and minimize transfer taxes to heirs. Which combined strategy accomplishes all goals?

options.A: CRAT funded with company stock, with heirs as remainder beneficiaries
options.B: CRT for income, with life insurance in ILIT replacing estate value for heirs
options.C: Direct sale with charitable bequest in will
options.D: Private foundation with family employment

questions.explanation: The 'wealth replacement' strategy uses a CRT (income to donor, remainder to charity) combined with an irrevocable life insurance trust (ILIT). Tax savings from the CRT fund insurance premiums. The ILIT replaces the asset value for heirs outside the estate.
questions.tip: CRT + ILIT = income for life, charity benefits, estate tax-free wealth replacement for heirs.
